snippet: The visitor arrived around 8 p.m. Wednesday, asking for the minister. It was unusual for a stranger, much less a white one, to come to Bible study, but the pastor welcomed him.
abstract: Detailed narrative of massacre at Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church and hours preceding it illustrate how bible study became site of tragedy; Rev Clementa C Pinckney had traveled from Columbia, SC, to participate in meeting; remained afterwards with other devout members for bible study, welcoming white stranger that would later be identified as Dylann Roof by police; Roof interrupted study to accuse blacks of 'taking over country' before opening fire.

byline.original: By RICHARD FAUSSET, JOHN ELIGON, JASON HOROWITZ and FRANCES ROBLES
byline.contributor: Richard Fausset and John Eligon reported from Charleston, and Jason Horowitz and Frances Robles from Columbia, S.C. Lizette Alvarez contributed reporting from Miami. Susan Beachy contributed research.

lead_paragraph: The visitor arrived around 8 p.m. Wednesday, asking for the minister. It was unusual for a stranger, much less a white one, to come to Bible study, but the pastor welcomed him.

headline.main: A Hectic Day at Charleston Church, and Then a Hellish Visitor
